fire.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: uncontrolled flames, light, and heat that destroy and damage things
fire.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: The warehouse was completely destroyed by fire.
Thirty people died in a fire in downtown Chicago.
Police think that the fire was started deliberately.
Rioters set fire to a whole row of stores  (=made them start burning).
Within minutes, the entire building was on fire.
fire.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: burning material used to heat a room, cook food etc, or get rid of things you do not want
fire.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: You put up the tent and I’ll make a fire.
Can you help me light the fire?
The fire has almost gone out  (=stopped burning).
They all sat around the camp fire, singing songs.
The fire was still smouldering in the grate  (=there was a little smoke and it had almost stopped burning).
Come and sit by the fire.
by the fire/in front of the fire
They dried their clothes in front of an open fire.
by the fire/in front of the fire
fire.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: a machine that produces heat to warm a room, using gas or electricity as power
turn the fire up/down (=make it hotter or colder)
fire.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: Turn on the fire, I’m cold.
fire.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: shots fired from a gun, especially many guns at the same time
fire.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: Troops opened fire on (=started shooting at) the demonstrators.
These women did vital work, often under enemy fire.
The rebels agreed to hold their fire (=not shoot).
fire.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: a very strong emotion that makes you want to think about nothing else
fire.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: – Meaning 1: uncontrolled flames, light, and heat that destroy and damage things
fire.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: The fire may have been started by a cigarette.
set fire to something/set something on fire
A candle fell over, setting fire to the curtains.
The boat caught fire and sank.
Further attempts to fight the fire were abandoned.
The fire was burning more strongly every minute.
A fire broke out in the engine room.
After several hours, the fire eventually went out.
Fires were raging in the forest near Magleby.
The fire spread to the house next door.
The school was badly damaged by fire.
The whole house was on fire within minutes.
Firefighters took more than an hour to bring the fire under control.
A big fire was raging at the fuel depot.
Greece has suffered many forest fires this year.
There were frequent brush fires during the hot dry summers.
Faulty electrical wiring is being blamed for a house fire.
fire.translation[0].note_box[1].heading: – Meaning 2: burning material used to heat a room, cook food etc, or get rid of things you do not want
fire.translation[0].note_box[1].sections: He found wood to make a fire.
It was too damp to light a fire.
Put another log on the fire.
They cooked strips of meat over a wood fire.
The fire was smouldering in the grate.
Sophie warmed herself by the open fire.
I sat by the roaring fire and dried off.
In the evening we sat around the camp fire.
There was a coal fire in the sitting room.
She lit the gas fire and settled in front of the TV.
There was a real fire blazing in the fireplace.
He stared at the glowing embers of the fire.
fire.translation[0].note_box[2].sections: flames that burn in an uncontrolled way and destroy or damage things
In April, a fire at the school destroyed the science block.
the bright parts of a fire that you see burning in the air
The flames from the burning building were lighting up the night sky.
a large and dangerous fire – used especially in news reports
Firemen fought to keep the blaze under control.
an extremely large and dangerous fire which is out of control – used especially in news reports
The entire building was on fire and hundreds of people were trapped in the inferno.
a very large fire that destroys a lot of buildings, trees etc
The conflagration spread rapidly through the old town.
fire.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: the sound of a gun being fired
Guerrillas fired five rockets at the capital yesterday, killing 23 people.
The police fired two shots at the suspects before they surrendered.
fire.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: to force someone to leave their job
fire.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: She didn’t want to get fired.
I’ve just been fired from my job, and I don’t know what to do.
The airline fired him for being drunk.
fire.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: to make someone feel interested in something and excited about it
fire.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: I was fired with enthusiasm to go traveling in Asia.
stories of magic and adventure that fire children’s imaginations
fire.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: to bake bricks, clay pots etc in a kiln
fire.translation[1].definitions[4].defin: if a vehicle’s engine fires, the petrol is lit to make the engine work
fire.translation[1].note_box[0].sections: to make someone leave their job, especially because they have done something wrong
He was fired for surfing the Internet during work time.
Harris was caught stealing, and was dismissed from his job.
sack/give somebody the sack
to make someone leave their job, especially because they are not good at it, or because they have done something wrong
Bates was sacked from his job after the team failed to win any games.
His boss gave him the sack for taking too much time off work.
lay somebody off
to make a lot of workers, especially workers in a large factory or organization, leave their jobs, because there is not enough work for them to do, or not enough money to pay their wages
3000 car workers have been laid off at the factory in Cleveland.
make somebody redundant
to make someone leave their job because they are no longer needed
5 staff will be made redundant at the end of this month.
let somebody go
to make someone leave their job, Used by employers to avoid saying directly that they are getting rid of people
We’ve had to let two members of staff go.
discharge
to make someone leave their job in the army, air force etc
Grant had been discharged from the navy for threatening an officer.
ease somebody out
to make someone leave their job in a way that makes it seem as if they have chosen to leave
He had been eased out of office in an attempt to prevent a political crisis.
relieve somebody of their post/position
to make someone leave their job because they have done something wrong – used especially to avoid saying this directly, and also when the job is a powerful one
The colonel and two other senior officers were relieved of their posts.
fire.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: to dismiss someone from their job
fire.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: Lee Iacocca worked his way up to the presidency of Ford Motor Company, from which he was abruptly fired by Henry Ford II.
The government aimed to sell off state assets and fire about 80,000 workers.
The airline fired him for being drunk.
